awd_titl_txt: DNA Repair Mechanisms of Self-Resistance to Genotoxic Secondary Metabolites
awd_abstract_narration:
DNA Repair Mechanisms of Self-Resistance to Genotoxic Secondary Metabolites

Bacteria, fungi, and plants produce secondary metabolites that often have antimicrobial properties, making these compounds important in agricultural, industrial, and medical applications. It therefore is important to understand how these compounds exert their toxicity and how the organisms that produce them can avoid self-destruction from toxicity of their own natural products. This research program will benefit society by providing 1) intensive quantitative structural biology experience in the laboratory to trainees at all levels, including postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate, 2) hands-on summer research opportunities to undergraduates of Fisk University, a nearby historically black college/university, 3) employment opportunities to women and underrepresented groups, 4) teaching and mentoring opportunities to all trainees, 5) exposure of high school students interested in STEM to biomedical research, and 5) community outreach. The appointment of the Principal Investigator in the College of Arts and Science and the School of Medicine at Vanderbilt University provides an exceptional collaborative and inclusive training environment. 

This project focuses on the duocarmycin/CC-1065/yatakemycin family of highly toxic natural products from Streptomyces that exhibit potent antimicrobial and antitumor properties by covalently modifying DNA. Recent work from our lab and others has established DNA base excision repair (BER) as a self-resistance mechanism for these and other genotoxic (DNA damaging) natural products. These self-resistance proteins are encoded within the biosynthetic gene clusters involved in synthesis and regulation of the natural products. While most work on biosynthetic gene clusters has focused on the enzymes that synthesize the natural product, the roles of the non-synthesis proteins, including those involved in self-resistance to toxicity, have lagged behind. The long-term goals of this project are to understand the roles of these self-protection mechanisms, which can lead to discovery of novel biological and biochemical mechanisms of the enzymes involved, and to increased yield of the natural product from a re-engineered producing organism. The short-term goal is to understand the specialized BER mechanism of duocarmycin/CC-1065/yatakemycin resistance in Streptomyces. Structural biology, biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology will be used to characterize the basis for toxicity of each compound and the specificity and mechanisms of the unique DNA glycosylases and apurinic endonucleases that catalyze the first two steps in BER of this important family of natural products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Bacteria, fungi, and plants produce secondary metabolites (a.k.a. natural products) that often have antimicrobial and antitumor properties, making these compounds important in agricultural, industrial, and medical applications. This research program focused on the cyclopropylpyrroloindole (CPI) family of genotoxic natural products, which includes duocarmycins, CC-1065, and yatakemycin, from Streptomyces that are highly toxic by virtue of their exquisite ability to bind to DNA. This research program aimed to understand how CPI-DNA adducts lead to cellular toxicity and how the producing bacteria utilize DNA base excision repair enzymes to evade this toxicity.

Intellectual Merit: This award resulted in 8 publications and led to discoveries that provide evidence for how DNA repair proteins have evolved in bacteria as self-resistance mechanisms against genotoxic secondary metabolites. We discovered that the extreme cytotoxicity of CPI-DNA adducts is the result of their ability to dramatically stabilize the DNA duplex and essentially form non-covalent interstrand DNA crosslinks (ICLs) through a network of CH-π interactions. We showed that AlkD family DNA glycosylases capable of removing CPI-DNA adducts from the DNA have evolved within the CPI biosynthesis gene clusters, and that reduced product affinity--not enhanced substrate recognition--by these enzymes is the evolutionary outcome of selective pressure to protect against yatakemycin and CC-1065. We also found that two exonucleases that reside within the yatakemycin biosynthesis gene cluster provide resistance to yatakemycin toxicity and that enzymatically remove the abasic site product of the glycosylase reaction, providing a mechanism for repairing the toxic DNA repair intermediates during base excision repair. In addition to the AlkD family of glycosylases that initiate repair CPI-DNA adducts, we characterized an unrelated family of DNA glycosylases that provide self-resistance against a wide range of DNA alkylating agents that form ICLs and base-intercalated adducts. DNA glycosylases have not been known to repair these types of DNA damage, and thus this research has opened the door to understanding a new class of DNA repair protein and to discover new genotoxins with bioactive potential.

Broader Impacts: This grant provided research support for five undergraduates, one graduate student, two postdoctoral research assistants, two technicians, one Lab Manager, and one Research Assistant Professor. Of these, four are from under-represented groups and seven are women. All trainees, including undergraduates, received practical experience and exposure to X-ray crystallography, electron microscopy, and other structural biology methods not usually taught at the undergraduate level, as well as training in lab safety and responsible conduct in research. Undergraduates were mentored by senior graduate students or postdocs, who in turn gained invaluable mentoring experience. The graduate student associated with the grant published six papers, served as a teaching assistant in undergraduate biochemistry, and was heavily engaged in collaborative outreach within the University and the community. The grant also provided training to four undergraduates from Fisk University, a nearby Historically Black College/University (HBCU). These students gained hands-on experience in basic molecular biology techniques as well as more advanced topics in protein/nucleic acid chemistry and structural biology. Former PhD-level trainees are now in industry positions, and undergraduates are in the process of applying to graduate or medical schools, and one is a first-year medical student.

 


Last Modified: 01/02/2025
Modified by: Brandt F Eichman
